title: NYSE Domino's cuts cost outlook after third-party delivery hit
text:
NYSE-listed Domino's Pizza surprised investors by resetting its long-term growth goals on Tuesday and said it would cut costs and investment this year as it battles the growing popularity of third-party delivery services and small pizzerias.

The company's shares, which fell 6 per cent on a results release that showed growth slowing and profit below expectations, recovered to trade up 4 per cent when executives laid out details of the spending plans on a call with analysts.

Chief financial officer Jeffrey Lawrence said he now expected general and administrative expenses to be between $US380 million and $US385 million in 2019, down from a previous range of $US390 million to $US395 million.

He also said Domino's would invest as much as $US20 million less than previously planned this year, prioritising its major investment projects.

Reaction was mixed to the company's move to replace its three- to five-year forecast with a shorter-term outlook which included lower percentage growth targets than those given previously for the longer period.

Chief executive Richard Allison said he did not know how long competitors delivering through Uber Eats, Postmates or GrubHub could maintain subsidised pricing, making it impossible to predict sales over the next five years.
description: Reaction was mixed to the US company's move to replace its three- to five-year forecast with a shorter-term outlook with lower percentage growth targets.
